segments.text: In the Army, things changed.
She became a commander and found herself awkwardly standing before the squad of recruits under her charge.
These recruits were tall, beautiful, and athletic.
All graduates of the Wingate Institute for Physical Education and a year older than her.
It was six in the morning, and according to protocol, she was supposed to lead them in morning exercises.
She thought to herself how embarrassing it was.
How could she lead them without being laughed at?
After all, they were the professionals.
Suddenly she heard herself say, look girls, from this morning until your short and basic training ends, every morning one of you will lead the exercise class for 15 minutes.
Who volunteers to be first?
Nama from the last row raised her hand and quickly stepped forward to stand beside her.
She smiled at her and without hesitation took the spot Nama left empty.
A moment later she followed Nama's instructions and all the girls smiled along with her.
The rest of the training day went as planned.
Everyone cooperated and precisely did everything she focused on.
In the evening, during the staff meeting, her officer said, That was a brilliant idea with the Morty exercises.
You really won over the girls.
But tomorrow, Dahlia will replace you, as you are going for officer assessments.
Leora lifted her head in surprise.
Everything was happening so quickly.
She wasn't even sure she wanted to be an officer.
After all, she had just finished the squad commander's course and didn't feel like starting another three-month course.
But she would take the assessments to see if she could even pass.
She needed to prove to herself that she could, as Zevik thought, as Rolf was convinced.
She so wanted to share with someone what happened to her over the weekend.
She wanted to tell Ruka, her new friend, who also slept in the bed next to hers.
But instead, when Ruka asked how the weekend was and where she had been, she told her she had been in Tel Aviv with her father and that it was very nice.
She noticed that the lies slipped from her mouth easily, without effort, as if protecting her secrets.
In her heart, she was glad that her days were busy, and that she didn't have too much time to think.
Ruka was envious, because Leora was sent for the assessments and she wasn't.
But still, she suddenly looked at her seriously and said, Well, it's no wonder.
You're more mature than all of us combined.
I don't know what it is about you, but there's always a feeling that nothing scares you.
You can feel it immediately.
Nonsense," Leora replied.
I'm not even sure I'll pass, and there's nothing to get excited about.
The next afternoon, when she returned to base after a grueling day of assessments that included a personal interview.
She stood in the shower, letting the water run over her for a long time.
She remembered the sentences she had to complete during the test, such as, I hate.
Talentless liars, she completed.
I was sad when.
The flowers became protected, she answered.
In the personal interview, she was asked to elaborate on these answers.
Apparently, they attracted attention.
Look, she said to the interviewer, I hate liars in general, but talentless liars whom you immediately realize are lying are especially detestable.
And regarding the flowers, what can I say?
I was fortunate to grow up in a wonderful time when you could cross a field and come back with a bouquet of wild flowers you picked yourself.
It's sad it won't happen again.
The flowers or the childhood, the interviewer pressed.
Both probably, she smiled at her, but a bouquet of wildflowers you picked on your own can always improve the situation.
Now the interviewer smiled from the other side of the table.
For a moment, the lines from Naomi Shemmers' Waltz for the Protection of the Plant replayed in her mind, which she used to sing jokingly to her friend Ruka.
No law protects only me.
No one guards only me.
If I had crown leaves, my condition would be different.
There's no way to beautify it.
These are lines of deep loneliness, still standing under the shower stream.
She knew without realizing it that she had become an accomplished and perhaps talented liar.
She just wanted the next two days to
Pass quickly so she could make her way home again.
Both Rolf and Zevik turned out to be right.
Just 20 days as an instructor, and she found herself in the officer's course.

Throughout those months since her enlistment, she received letters from Rolf overseas, all with edges trimmed by military censorship, which was probably sure she was sharing military secrets with him.
His letters arrived each time from a different country, and no wonder it raised questions.
But even though she understood, it drove her crazy and made her very angry.
Only once she started reading did she calm down.
She often thought about the soldier reading her love letters in English and wondered what he thought.
One day, after she received her officer ranks and sent him a picture from the ceremony, she received a thick letter from him.
And for the first time, censorship spared it.
It was from Brazil where Rolf had been for several months.
She took the letter, sat in a shaded corner on the edge of the base, and began to read.
My dear, I'm in a terrible hangover since yesterday, after longing overwhelmed me and I drank a bit too much, maybe a lot too much.
Last night I entered a bar in the center of Sao Paulo, which was almost empty of people.
I sat at the bar, exchanged a few sentences with the bartender, and he said my blue eyes and fair hair betray my European origin.
I told him I'm from Switzerland.
He began to pour me a beer.
tilting the glass just like you do, and suddenly I started talking, unable to stop.
And he, like a good bartender who knows how to listen, didn't interrupt me even once.
I'm here for work, I told him, almost three months.
Before that I was two months home in Switzerland, and two months in Germany and Italy.
But before that, I was in a small coastal city in Israel for nine months, and there I left my heart with a young girl much younger than me.
who just finished the officer training coursing the army.
I simply one evening pushed open the door of her home, which is also a small hotel, dived into her eyes and remained captivated.

It's not obvious to come to a place like Israel after being in half the world, and precisely there, in a small town by the sea, find a girl, not quite a woman, with the maturity and insights of an adult, with a simple beauty that asks nothing for embellishment.
Barefoot.
in jeans and a t-shirt with a book in hand or fingers hovering on piano keys in wonderful melodies, depending on her mood.
And she knows how to pour beer like a bartender and make a good sandwich when you're hungry.
And she speaks her life like a story.
A girl who on some days holds entirely on her own a small hotel, which is also a bar and a restaurant.
And all its walls are covered with paintings her father painted when he emerged from time to time from his wanderings in the big city.
From the day I met her for the first time, I couldn't leave.
I would arrive almost every evening for a beer and something to eat.
Sometimes there were two or three other people, but most of the time we were alone, talking about our lives and dreams.
That's how it was for long weeks until I was absent for a week and when I returned.
We simply fell into each other's arms, as if it was our natural place always.
We had days of great happiness.
The sadness in her eyes, which had been there since her mother passed away a year and a half earlier, almost disappeared.
I saw a new, bright light in them.
I was so happy to know that's what I caused her.
and she was barely 18, but there is no one like her.
A kind of wild, intelligent and talented growth, as free as a butterfly.
A barefoot butterfly.
For the closing party of the project at the factory where I worked, I took her and bought her a small dress and heels, simply because she had no clothes of that kind.

She gathered her hair just in a ponytail tied back, without any makeup, just the blue of her eyes and especially everything that's shown from them, and walked confidently in those heels, even though it was her first time.
And I immediately knew she could be both.
a barefoot girl in jeans and A. T-shirt and also a young woman in a dress and heels, and both suited her equally, and it didn't matter if her hair was loose or tied in a ponytail or braid.

Her eyes were what mattered, and everything within them, that warmth and her wisdom, and her lack of fear of life, braver than me, experienced with people knowing how to navigate them, opinionated but graceful, radiant, barely 18 but knowing life.
And so we entered the party hall, and suddenly I felt all eyes fixed on us.
I realized they were fixed on her, because the whole small town knew her because of their hotel, but they had never seen her like this, only in short jeans in the summer and long ones in the winter.
always with a tank top or t-shirt and mostly barefoot.
And suddenly this barefoot duckling stands before them in a delicate dress and high heels, with her hair tied back, looking like a swan.
How proud I was.
They had troubles with their house because of her mother's illness, who was sick for a long month until she passed away.
Her father hospitalized her in a private hospital with a personal professor, which cost a fortune and plunged him into heavy debts.
And there was also the other daughter of the mother from previous marriages, who insisted on getting her share of the inheritance and involved lawyers and courts until they ultimately lost the house.
On the day she enlisted, I took her early in the morning to the enlistment office, and we stood embraced for maybe 15 minutes, refusing to let go.
Knowing the whole world was about to change, because in two weeks I leave, and in two weeks the pink house will no longer be there.
My heart went out to her.
What would happen to her?
What would happen to us?
It wasn't easy to lose a house like that.
It was a whole world.
Her parents created it with their own hands.
And all their character and culture were intertwined in every corner.
The paintings on the walls, the amazing garden surrounding it, a house that enveloped you as soon as you entered, even though you were a complete stranger.

and she, this little one, clung to it to the last minute, trying to preserve every corner, cleaning, arranging, watering the garden, telling me it was for her mom, just in case she was looking from above, so she wouldn't be sorry the garden was withered.
But now she already knew it wouldn't help.
That's it.
The house is gone, just like her mom, and there's nothing to be done.
I never saw her shed a tear even once.

She packed her entire short life into two small cartons, all her treasures, her books and a few special records, very few clothes, two pairs of shoes, one pair of boots, and a few empty bottles of Madame Rocha's, her mother's perfume.
She wanted to remember her scent.
I saw her a week later, when she came for a weekend leave, and I brought her a big teddy bear to have something to hug when I leave.
And in our last farewell hug, only when she saw the tears welling in my eyes, did she also release hers, and the saltiness and sorrow mingled together.
And that was it.
I didn't see her again.
We only exchanged endless letters, trying to hold on to each other, almost knowing there was no purpose in it, yet still maybe.
I had no doubt they would quickly understand her nature and make her an officer.
I told her that before she enlisted and, behold, I was right.
Now I worry about her a little less because being an officer can also be a profession and she can make a living if she wants.
Sometimes I wake up in the middle of the night and decide that tomorrow morning I'll board a plane and fly to her.
Then, as morning dawns, I realize it's futile and that I need to let her continue with her life and try to continue mine.
I'm here in Sao Paulo at the world's end, and I can tell you that whoever coined the phrase out of sight, out of mind, simply doesn't know what they're talking about.
Like this, in one breath, when I was completely drunk and told him our entire story.
Good night, my love.
Rolf.
She held the letter in both hands and slowly let it fall onto her lap, understanding from the lines in his very noble way that he was releasing her to her path.
